awd_titl_txt: Tropical and nonarchimedean analytic methods in algebraic geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Algebraic geometry studies solution sets of systems of polynomial equations.  For instance, lines are solution sets of linear polynomial equations, while circles and hyperbolas are solution sets to quadratic polynomial equations, and their study goes back to the ancient Greeks. The solution sets of systems of many polynomial equations in many variables often have beautiful and complicated geometry. The PI will apply new and modern techniques to answer questions of classical interest in the field of algebraic geometry, and to address long standing open problems about the geometry of curves defined by polynomial equations. This project provides research training opportunities for graduate students.

Over a nonarchimedean field, one can split the problem of understanding such solution sets into two parts. What are the possible valuations of solutions?  And what are the solutions with a given valuation?  The set of valuations of solutions has a rich combinatorial and polyhedral structure, and is the primary object of study in tropical geometry; the solutions with a given valuation can be studied via nonarchimedean analytic geometry.  Recent developments in these fields make it possible to resolve subtle questions about the geometry of the actual solution set using new and innovative tools and techniques. This project will refine, abstract, and generalize these new methods and explore deeper applications to open problems in algebraic geometry.The PI will use tropical and nonarchimedean methods to continue his work on refined curve counting, and on unstable cohomology of moduli spaces of curves, proceeding beyond the top graded piece of the weight filtration to examine the full weight-graded cohomology ring. He will also initiate an analogous study of the weight graded cohomology of the moduli space of abelian varieties, using the topology of moduli spaces of tropical abelian varieties and the combinatorial algebra of complexes built out of unimodular matroids and perfect quadratic forms. Additional projects will attack the motivic, p-adic, and topological monodromy conjectures for Newton nondegenerate singularities, using the combinatorics of relative local h-polynomials and Stapledon’s formulas for monodromy, and attempt to resolve outstanding (and mutually contradictory) conjectures of Kontsevich and Morita in the homology of commutative graph complexes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Algebraic geometry studies varieties described locally as solution sets of systems of polynomial equations. Over a nonarchimedean field, one can split the problem of understanding such solution sets into two parts. What are the valuations of solutions? And what are the solutions with a given valuation? The set of valuations of solutions has rich combinatorial structure, and is the primary object of study in tropical geometry. The set of solutions with a given valuation is a nonarchimedean analytic domain, suitable for study as a Berkovich space. Combining techniques from both yields a powerful strategy for attacking open problems in algebraic geometry.In this project, the PI and his collaborators used such tropical and nonarchimedean methods to study the unstable cohomology of moduli spaces of curves and moduli spaces of principally polarized abelian varieties. In particular, they computed the compactly supported cohomology of moduli spaces of curves in weights 2 and 11. This work confirmed predictions from number theory and lead to new insights on the number of isomorphism classes of curves of fixed genus over a finite field.

They also computed the weight zero cohomology of the moduli space of principally polarized abelian varieties and showed that it carries remarkable structure — it is a bigraded Hopf algebra, graded by cohomological degree and genus. Along the way, they found analogous new structures in the unstable cohomology of GL_n(Z) and SL_n(Z) and discovered new relations between the cohomology of the symplectic group Sp_{2g}(Z) and the algebraic K-theory K(Z). Furthermore, they proved the motivic monodromy conjecture for singularities that are nondegenerate with respect to a simplicial Newton polyhedron.

All of these results give new insights into the intricate relationship between geometry, topology, and number theory in the study of algebraic varieties and their moduli. 

This project also provided support and professional development opportunities for five PhD students and four postdocs working directly with the PI in his research group. In this way, the project contributed to training the next generation of researchers in this active field and helped nine young mathematicians proceed successfully into the next stages of their careers.
